articles.headline: Costly Drone Is Poised to Replace U-2 Spy Plane
articles.snippet: Despite countless delays and budget battles, the Air Force is betting that a $12 billion program of unmanned drones is ready to gather intelligence from heights only dreamed of.
articles.abstract: Despite countless delays and budget battles, the Air Force is betting that a $12 billion program of unmanned drones is ready to gather intelligence from heights only dreamed of.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALMDALE, Calif. — Tucked away here in the Mojave Desert, the assembly plant for the high-flying Global Hawk jet resembles a giant hobby shop.

articles.headline: Stalemate in Senate Leaves 4,000 Out of Work at F.A.A.
articles.snippet: The partial agency shutdown is likely to continue through Labor Day and relies on airport safety inspectors to keep working without pay.
articles.abstract: The partial agency shutdown is likely to continue through Labor Day and relies on airport safety inspectors to keep working without pay.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After dealing with the debt crisis, Senate negotiators tried and failed on Tuesday to end a stalemate over temporary financing for the Federal Aviation Administration, leaving 4,000 agency employees out of work and relying on airport safety inspectors to continue working without pay.

articles.headline: AAA Rating Is a Rarity in Business
articles.snippet: Hanging over the debt ceiling talks has been the threat of the United States losing its AAA credit rating, but in corporate America, the top status long ago became an anachronism.
articles.abstract: Hanging over the debt ceiling talks has been the threat of the United States losing its AAA credit rating, but in corporate America, the top status long ago became an anachronism.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hanging over the debt ceiling negotiations in Washington has been the threat that the United States could lose its AAA credit rating, a coveted measure of the federal government’s financial strength. But in corporate America, the top rating long ago became an anachronism.

articles.headline: Turkey Plant May Be Salmonella Link
articles.snippet: Federal officials are investigating whether a single processing plant is responsible for a salmonella outbreak that has killed one person and sickened 76 others.
articles.abstract: Federal officials are investigating whether a single processing plant is responsible for a salmonella outbreak that has killed one person and sickened 76 others.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal officials said on Tuesday that they were investigating an apparent link between ground turkey meat and a nationwide outbreak of salmonella illness that has so far killed one person in California and sickened at least 76 more people in 26 states.

articles.headline: Teenager’s Path and a Killing Put Spotlight on Mental Care
articles.snippet: Pericles Clergeau was shuttled through various Massachusetts agencies that were supposed to help him.
articles.abstract: Pericles Clergeau was shuttled through various Massachusetts agencies that were supposed to help him.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOWELL, Mass. — Pericles Clergeau, a tall, sturdy teenager with a troubled past, did not much like it when Kevin Allard, a radiant, sometimes manic youth, arrived at Adolescent Unit 2 at the Westborough state psychiatric hospital early last year.

articles.headline: Spending Cuts Seen as Step, Not as Cure
articles.snippet: At the end of the 10-year period covered by the debt deal, the federal debt will be much larger than today.
articles.abstract: At the end of the 10-year period covered by the debt deal, the federal debt will be much larger than today.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There is something you should know about the deal to cut federal spending that President Obama signed into law on Tuesday: It does not actually reduce federal spending.

articles.headline: Cubans Set for Big Change: Right to Buy Homes
articles.snippet: Cuba is planning to legalize the sale and purchase of property, and some predict that it could produce broad changes in society.
articles.abstract: Cuba is planning to legalize the sale and purchase of property, and some predict that it could produce broad changes in society.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAVANA — José is an eager almost-entrepreneur with big plans for Cuban real estate. Right now he works illegally on trades, linking up families who want to swap homes and pay a little extra for an upgrade.

articles.headline: For Strong and Weak, Debt Pressures Rattle Europe
articles.snippet: With the dollar withering under the United States debt trouble, the Swiss franc is as good as gold — a situation the Swiss National Bank moved to stifle.
articles.abstract: With the dollar withering under the United States debt trouble, the Swiss franc is as good as gold — a situation the Swiss National Bank moved to stifle.
articles.lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The almighty dollar used to be the world’s safest refuge in times of trouble. But what do you do when you are worried about the dollar, as many people are now?

articles.headline: At Mubarak Trial, Stark Image of Humbled Power
articles.snippet: Egypt’s ousted president, Hosni Mubarak, denied charges of corruption and complicity in killing protesters.
articles.abstract: Egypt’s ousted president, Hosni Mubarak, denied charges of corruption and complicity in killing protesters.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — An ailing Hosni Mubarak, who had served longer than any other ruler of modern Egypt until a revolution toppled him in February, was rolled into a courtroom in a hospital bed on Wednesday to face charges of corruption and complicity in the killing of protesters, offering an indelible lesson for Egypt and the Arab world in the humbling of power.

articles.headline: Casting Aside World Criticism, Syria Invades Town
articles.snippet: Syria ordered its military to storm through the city of Hama after three days of shelling.
articles.abstract: Syria ordered its military to storm through the city of Hama after three days of shelling.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Ignoring mounting condemnations, the Syrian military sent tanks, armored vehicles and snipers on Wednesday into the symbolic center of Hama, a rebellious city that has emerged as a linchpin of the nearly five-month uprising, in what appeared a decisive step by President Bashar al-Assad to crush opposition to his rule.
